data.title: Here Are the Best and Worst States for Taxes. Guess Which Ranks Last? — Barrons.com
data.description:
By Kenneth Corbin

State tax codes, like their federal counterpart, can be incredibly complex and are subject to frequent revisions. But the absence of a major tax — such as a sales tax, or levies on corporate or individual income — is a theme of many of the states that top a new ranking of tax policies around the country.

The Tax Foundation, a nonpartisan think tank that often favors policies to reduce or simplify tax burdens, looked at more than 150 variables to compile its annual ranking of the most and least favorable states, published on Thursday.

The winner? Wyoming, a sparsely populated western state with no corporate or individual income tax, tops the Tax Foundation's list. South Dakota, a state with a similar profile that also doesn't tax corporate or individual income, is No. 2.

The others in the Tax Foundation's top five also don't impose one or more of the major taxes. New Hampshire and Alaska, which both don't have a statewide sales tax or individual income tax, ranked Nos. 3 and 4, respectively. Florida, which has no individual income tax, ranked No. 5 on the list.

At the other end of the spectrum, the Tax Foundation ranked New York the state with the worst tax environment. The researchers cited its high individual income rate, the benefit recapture policy that phases out benefits from lower rates, and the imposition of local taxes in areas like New York City, among other factors.

The ranking's methodology weighs factors such as rates and complexity and groups the variables it considers into the five categories of corporate taxes, individual income taxes, sales and excise taxes, property and wealth taxes, and unemployment insurance taxes.

The Tax Foundation dinged the second-lowest ranked state, New Jersey, for levying taxes in all the major categories, "typically at high rates and significant levels of complexity."

The group awarded California the third-lowest spot on the list, followed by Connecticut and Maryland.

It cites California's high rates and a tax structure the researchers say is hostile to businesses, including the assessment of corporate tax on certain out-of-state income that would be tax-free in other states. "The state has a great deal going for it," the researchers say, citing California's research universities, moderate climate, and Silicon Valley, "but a tax code that is uncompetitive and threatens to get worse is increasingly driving jobs to other states."

Connecticut gets a poor score both because of its high rates and an individual tax code that is "one of the most complex" and progressive in the country, the analysts say.

Maryland has one of the most progressive individual tax codes in the country, and state lawmakers recently created two new tax brackets for the highest earners, according to the Tax Foundation's analysis.

Among the states the Tax Foundation deems most favorable, Wyoming and South Dakota, Nos. 1 and 2, are the only two states that don't tax corporate or individual income and don't impose a gross receipts tax, which applies to a company's gross sales.

The analysts lauded New Hampshire for taking steps to make its corporate tax structure more competitive and noted that it phased out taxes on interest and dividends at the beginning of this year, "further solidifying the state's competitive standing."

Alaska ranks highly due to its lack of individual income tax and sales tax, but the Tax Foundation notes that it could improve its policy framework by lowering corporate and property taxes and blocking cities and boroughs from setting their own sales-tax rates.

The Tax Foundation credits Florida for not imposing an individual income-tax rate and having a reasonable corporate rate, as well as a sales tax rate that is lower than many other southern states.

This content was created by Barron's, which is operated by Dow Jones & Co. Barron's is published independently from Dow Jones Newswires and The Wall Street Journal.

data.title: Scor shares fall 13% amid market concern around underlying trends
data.description:
By Ashish Tiwari

(The Insurer) - Scor's share price was down by around 13% when markets closed on Friday amid investor concern around underlying trends in the group's third-quarter results, published earlier in the day.

Scor reported a net income of 217 million euros, about 6.7% above consensus, and an annualised return on equity of 22.1%, beating expectations of 18.8%.

The earnings beat was helped by lower natural catastrophe losses, with the group’s combined ratio improving to 80.9% from an expected 82.3%, supported by mild weather and disciplined underwriting.

However, its life and health business fell short of expectations by about 11%, with the segment reporting a result of 98 million euros versus a consensus of 110 million euros.

Jefferies analysts said the earnings beat was “largely due to the lack of natural catastrophes,” noting that underlying P&C margins were lower than expected and that real estate amortisation and higher onerous contracts in the life business weighed on results.

Analysts at J.P. Morgan said the results “beat expectations at the headline level,” but that “the underlying details do not appear quite as favourable,” calling it “not the best quarter.”

The bank said the life business and solvency ratio both performed weaker than expected.

Scor’s Solvency II ratio also came in at 210%, below the market forecast of 213%, though still within its 185–220% target range.

KBW’s Darius Satkauskas said the results were “somewhat mixed,” adding that discounting effects and lower catastrophe activity flattered the combined ratio.

“The underlying figures do not look as strong,” Satkauskas said, though he pointed out that the group continues to build prudence into reserves.

Satkauskas said disclosure limitations and management's "somewhat vague" answers during the group's earnings call had not helped restore market confidence after Scor's earlier results announcement.

Scor shares fell 12.98% during Friday's trading, closing at 26.28 euros.

data.title: Norway's Vianode to build synthetic graphite plant for EV batteries in Ontario
data.description:
Key points:
  • Says first phase requires $1.43 billion investment
  • Production expected to start late 2028
  • Canadian government to support funding of the plant, Vianode says

By Nick Carey

Norway's Vianode will build a multi-billion-dollar synthetic graphite plant in Ontario to supply anode materials for EV batteries and is in talks to supply defense and energy storage customers keen to find non-Chinese sources of this critical mineral, it said on Friday.

China controls 95% of the global supply of graphite, which is vital for electric vehicle battery production.

Vianode said the initial investment for the plant will be 2 billion Canadian dollars ($1.43 billion), which should start production in late 2028. Planned expansions will bring total capacity of up to 150,000 metric tons annually by the early 2030s, enough for around 2 million EVs.

CEO Burkhard Straube told Reuters the plant will be funded by customer agreements, equity and support from the Canadian government. The announcement came during a meeting of energy and environment ministers from the Group of Seven hosted by Canada, as China leverages its grip on critical minerals like rare earths in trade talks.

SLOWING EV DEMAND DELAYS PRODUCTION

"Canada is proud to support Vianode in advancing critical mineral development that aligns with our national priorities and international commitments," Canada's Minister of Energy and Natural Resources Tim Hogdson said in a statement.

Vianode originally planned to launch production in 2027, but slowing U.S. EV demand had delayed it, Straube said.

Automakers are backpedaling hard on U.S. EV plans following the expiration of a $7,500 federal tax credit for EV buyers on September 30.

In January, General Motors signed a multi-billion-dollar agreement for Vianode to provide synthetic graphite anode materials for EV batteries. But on Wednesday GM said it would cut U.S. EV and battery production and factory jobs in Detroit and Ohio.

GM CEO Mary Barra had told shareholders last week that EVs remained the automaker's "North Star."

"We see a slowdown right now in electromobility," Vianode's Straube said. "But electromobility is here to stay."

He said while most of the talks Vianode is holding are with automakers, others are focused on defense projects.

"The volume in the defense industry is smaller than other industries," Straube said. "But the strategic importance of defense is very, very high."

($1 = 1.4024 Canadian dollars)

data.title: G7 Unveils Deals Aimed at Bolstering Developed World's Critical-Mineral Capacity
data.description:
By Paul Vieira

Energy envoys from the Group of Seven economies unveiled in Toronto on Friday about two dozen deals aimed at unlocking billions worth of critical minerals.

Canadian Energy and Resources Minister Tim Hodgson said the transactions mark a coordinated effort to counter China's dominance in the field.

"We are serious about reducing market concentration and dependencies, safeguarding national security and sovereignty, mobilizing capital and driving investments in sustainable critical minerals projects," he said, according to prepared remarks he was scheduled to deliver. Canada is leading the G7 presidency this year.

The deals include offtake agreements, in which there's a commitment to buy a miner's production, and stockpiling pacts, in which a party agrees to acquire and store production for future use. Some of the Canada-focused deals include financing for Nouveau Monde Graphite's mine near Montreal, and Rio Tinto's scandium plant in Quebec.

Hodgson added that Italian energy company Eni has indicated its intention to pursue critical minerals opportunities in Canada, such as lithium and graphite.

Overall, he said the deals would unlock about $4.5 billion in critical-minerals projects.

Meanwhile, Hodgson added Canada's cabinet had issued an order to designate critical minerals as "essential to Canadian defense and national interests," thereby allowing Canada to launch its own defense-stockpiling regime. "By protecting domestic production under volatile global conditions, we ensure a secure supply of critical minerals to Canadian and allied defence industries."

Canada has tried to champion closer integration among the big Western developed economies on the production of critical minerals. Since the 1990s, China has used aggressive tactics to build up and maintain its lock over rare-earth minerals, which are essential to making magnets needed for cars, wind turbines, jet fighters and other products.

China has imposed restrictions this year, including a sudden move in October to tighten curbs on rare-earth exports. In a meeting Thursday between President Trump and Chinese leader Xi Jinping, Beijing promised to ease some of the controls it imposed on exports of processed rare-earth minerals for one year.

Write to Paul Vieira at paul.vieira@wsj.com

data.title: Brazilian prosecutors investigate illegal use of native wood in corn ethanol production
data.description:
Key points:
  • Prosecutors in Mato Grosso state to investigate illegal use of native wood as fuel for corn ethanol industry
  • State reforesters association Arefloresta says over 50% of wood used in sector is from native trees
  • Corn ethanol producer FS says its 87,000 hectares of planted forest meet all needs

By Roberto Samora

The Brazilian state of Mato Grosso is investigating whether corn ethanol plants are burning wood from illegal deforestation to produce the biofuel, running counter to decarbonization goals in the sector, prosecutor Ana Luiza Peterlini told Reuters.

Mato Grosso is Brazil's top soybean producer and accounts for two-thirds of the country's corn ethanol output, which has exploded in recent years. The investigation by state prosecutors seeks to determine if plants are illegally burning native wood to generate energy in the production process, Peterlini said.

While processing plants should use planted trees to fuel boilers, some are burning native wood at about half the price, according to a complaint sent to prosecutors.

"I will investigate, for sure. The hypothesis that these companies are using raw material from deforestation already goes against the industry's own logic," Peterlini said, referring to the lower carbon footprint of the renewable fuel.

TOP EMISSIONS SOURCE

Brazil has been a leader in biofuels adoption, but deforestation is the largest source of greenhouse gas emissions in the country, which hosts the next United Nations climate summit in November.

The government touted an 11% drop in deforestation of the Amazon rainforest in the 12 months through July. Still, 5,796 square kilometers of the jungle were destroyed in the period.

Prosecutors will question Mato Grosso environmental agency Sema about a 2022 rule that allows the use of native biomass in industry, which could be at odds with the federal forest code, Peterlini said.

If confirmed, Peterlini would recommend revoking the rule, she said, citing the difficulty of tracking the origin of wood burned in boilers.

The Mato Grosso Reforesters Association (Arefloresta) says more than half of the wood used in corn ethanol production comes from the felling of native trees.

"Today, more than 50% of the wood consumed in the corn ethanol sector is native," Arefloresta President Clair Bariviera told Reuters.

Illegal wood is significantly cheaper, Bariviera said, at around half the price of planted eucalyptus.

EUCALYPTUS SHORTAGE

Ten corn ethanol plants currently operate in Mato Grosso and regulator ANP has given the greenlight to build seven more, according to the National Corn Ethanol Union (Unem), which said eight more plants are in the planning phase.

According to Arefloresta 30,000 hectares of planted eucalyptus forests would be needed to fuel a projected 13.5 million metric tons of corn milled for ethanol in 2025/26, if that were the only wood burned in the boilers.

While some 140,000 hectares of eucalyptus are planted statewide, the sector provides wood burning from just 15,000 hectares each year, with most of the trees harvested for the paper industry. Supply is tight, Bariviera said, because planted forests take six to seven years to mature.

"I've been president of the association for three years, and we've been fighting to plant forests in the state, saying biomass will run short — and it will," Bariviera said.

Unem declined to comment on biomass supply or the issues raised in prosecutors' pending investigation. Sema did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

Brazil's top corn ethanol producer Inpasa, which has two plants in Mato Grosso, said it strictly follows Brazilian law and its biomass meets the highest compliance standards

FS, which has three plants in Mato Grosso, said it has 87,000 hectares of planted forests, including eucalyptus and bamboo, adding that these assets were developed over the past eight years and can supply all operations and expansion plans.

data.title: Canada to accelerate critical mineral projects worth $4.6 billion, energy minister says
data.description:
By Divya Rajagopal

Canada will accelerate mining projects worth C$6.4 billion ($4.6 billion), as part of the Critical Minerals Production Alliance, Energy and Natural Resources Minister Tim Hodgson said on Friday. The announcement came at the end of the two-day Group of Seven meeting of energy and environment ministers in Toronto.

Hodgson said that Canada and its G7 partners will mobilize public and private capital to fast-track graphite, rare earth elements, and scandium production. As part of this alliance, Canada said it has signed an offtake agreement for scandium and graphite with Australian miner Rio Tinto, and Quebec-based Nouveau Monde Graphite. An offtake agreement is a deal where a buyer agrees to purchase a producer's output in the future for a predetermined price.

Earlier this week, in an interview with Reuters, Hodgson said that Canada intended to be a leader in securing supply chains for all of its key allies, to reduce reliance on China. Canada produces several critical metals such as nickel, copper, and cobalt.

G7 countries, except Japan, are heavily or exclusively reliant on China for a range of materials from rare earth magnets to battery metals.

data.title: Howmet Aerospace Is Maintained at Buy by TD Cowen
California City of Manteca to Sell $48 Million of Wastewater Revenue Bonds
data.description:
By Chris Wack

The Manteca Financing Authority of California plans to issue $48 million of bonds to finance improvements in its wastewater system.

Proceeds from the Series 2025 Wastewater Revenue Bonds will also be used to refinance the Series 2009 sewer revenue bonds and City of Manteca Series 2012 sewer revenue bonds, according to a document posted Thursday on MuniOS.

The bonds will provide about $30 million for improvements to Manteca's wastewater system, including work on a dewatering unit, a sludge thickener unit, and the wastewater system's collection system.

Pricing is scheduled for Nov. 6 and closing is set for Nov. 25.

The bonds are special obligations of the authority and repayment is secured by a pledge of revenue from the wastewater system of the city.

Interest is payable starting on June 1 and again Dec. 1. The securities are subject to optional redemption starting on Dec. 1, 2035. The bonds reach final maturity in December 2055.

The Manteca Financing Authority was created in 1991 for the purpose of issuing bonds to finance the purchase, construction and improvement of certain capital improvements for the city. Located in San Joaquin County, Manteca is about 75 miles east of San Francisco.

S&P Global Ratings assigned the bonds a rating of AA.

Ramirez & Co. is lead underwriter.

Write to Chris.Wack@wsj.com

data.title: AMERIPRISE FINANCIAL INC SEC 10-Q Report
data.description:
Ameriprise Financial Inc., a leading diversified financial services company, has released its Form 10-Q report for the second quarter of 2025. The report highlights significant growth in both financial and operational metrics, underscoring the company's robust performance and strategic initiatives.

Financial Highlights

Ameriprise Financial Inc. reported impressive financial results for the second quarter of 2025, showcasing strong growth across key metrics:

  • Total Revenues: $4,893 million, reflecting a growth from $4,560 million in the prior year period, driven by increased management and financial advice fees.
  • Total Net Revenues: $4,791 million, up from $4,397 million, indicating strong performance in core business areas.
  • Net Income: $912 million, a significant increase from $511 million, showcasing improved profitability.
  • Basic Earnings Per Share (EPS): $9.47, compared to $5.09, highlighting enhanced shareholder value.
  • Diluted EPS: $9.33, up from $5.00, reflecting the company's strong earnings growth.

Business Highlights

The company's operational performance was equally robust, with notable achievements across various segments and initiatives:

  • Revenue Segments: The company reported revenue from contracts with customers across several segments, including Advice & Wealth Management, Asset Management, and Retirement & Protection Solutions. The Advice & Wealth Management segment generated significant revenue from advisory fees, financial planning fees, and transaction and other fees. Asset Management revenue was driven by asset management fees from retail and institutional clients, while the Retirement & Protection Solutions segment contributed through insurance and annuity distribution fees.
  • Geographical Performance: The company's commercial mortgage loans are diversified across U.S. regions, with significant concentrations in the Pacific and South Atlantic regions, which together account for over 60% of the total commercial mortgage loan portfolio.
  • Sales Units: The company reported a total of $1,993 million in commercial mortgage loans, with a significant portion of these loans having a loan-to-value ratio of less than 60%, indicating a strong credit quality.
  • New Product Launches: During the second quarter of 2025, the company launched a new Collateralized Loan Obligation (CLO), which issued debt of $406 million, expanding its offerings in asset-backed financing.
  • Future Outlook: The company is assessing changes to income tax-related disclosures due to new accounting standards, which are expected to enhance transparency in financial reporting. Additionally, the company is evaluating the impact of new standards on the accounting for internal-use software, which may affect future operational strategies.

SEC Filing: AMERIPRISE FINANCIAL INC [ AMP ] - 10-Q - Oct. 31, 2025

data.title: Nexperia cuts wafer supplies to Chinese plant, ratcheting up chip disruptions
data.description:
Key points:
  • Nexperia suspends wafer shipments, citing lack of payment
  • Automakers alarmed over possible impact on production
  • Nexperia seeking alternative solutions to keep customers supplied

By Che Pan and Wen-Yee Lee

Dutch chipmaker Nexperia has suspended supplies of wafers to its Chinese assembly plant, according to a letter addressed to its customers that was reviewed by Reuters, which could exacerbate a supply squeeze that is worrying automakers worldwide.

The letter, dated October 29 and signed by Nexperia interim CEO Stefan Tilger, said the October 26 suspension affecting its plant in Dongguan, in southern China's Guangdong province, was "a direct consequence of the local management's recent failure to comply with the agreed contractual payment terms."

Nexperia has been locked in a dispute with its Chinese unit after the Dutch government took control of Nexperia from its Chinese owner Wingtech Technology (600745.S) on September 30. It also removed its Chinese CEO, citing concerns that its technology could be appropriated by Wingtech.

Nexperia's Chinese unit had resumed supplying semiconductors to local customers but stipulated that all sales to distributors would need to be settled using the Chinese yuan. Previously, transactions had been in foreign currencies like the U.S. dollar.

LARGE VOLUMES OF CHIPS

The company produces large volumes of chips in the Netherlands that are widely used in the automotive and consumer electronics industries. Some 70% of the European-produced chips are packaged in China and sold mostly to distributors.

"While we have maintained shipments for as long as commercially feasible, continuing the current flow of supply from our front-end sites is no longer justifiable," the letter said.

"Unless these contractual obligations are fully satisfied, we cannot resume wafer supply to the site. Nexperia is developing alternative solutions to ensure (that) supply (is) continuing to our customers."

Nexperia added that the decision did not reflect an intention to withdraw from its site in Dongguan or the Chinese market as a whole, adding that it remained committed to finding a resolution.

Nexperia said it is financially independent of Wingtech and it does not raise capital from Wingtech, the letter showed.

A spokesperson for Nexperia confirmed it sent the letter and the company could not comment further. Nexperia China did not immediately respond to requests for comment. Wingtech declined to comment.

A Dutch government spokesperson referred questions about the wafer shut-off to Nexperia, saying the move had been a corporate decision while state intervention "concerns the preservation of production capacity and is not aimed at the company's day-to-day operations".

The Netherlands is in discussions with European governments and the European Commission, as well as Chinese authorities, "to work toward a constructive solution," the spokesperson said.

EU tech chief Henna Virkkunen said after a meeting with Nexperia management on Friday that they are working toward a "diplomatic breakthrough" to resolve the situation, but in the meantime they are looking at unspecified short- and medium-term measures to relieve European industry.

IMPACT ON PRODUCTION

Court filings showed that the seizure by the Dutch government came as U.S. pressure was rising on Nexperia after Wingtech was placed on a restricted-export list, though Dutch authorities say governance shortcomings were the trigger.

On October 4, China's commerce ministry blocked Nexperia from exporting chips from China.

Industry bodies have sounded the alarm over the possible impact on production, with Stellantis saying on Thursday that it had set up a "war room" to monitor the situation.

Japanese automaker Nissan said it had enough chips to last until the first week of November without disruption.

Some Nexperia products that used to cost just a few Chinese cents have gone up to two or three yuan each over the past two weeks, more than 10 times their original price, according to a source familiar with the matter.

data.title: World Bank arbitration body rejects Barrick expedition request in Mali case, sources say
data.description:
By Portia Crowe and Divya Rajagopal

A request by Barrick Mining to expedite its international arbitration case against Mali has been rejected, two people familiar with the matter told Reuters on Friday.

The West African country's government has been in fraught negotiations with Barrick since 2023 over the implementation of a new mining code that raises taxes and gives the government a greater share of its gold mines.

Barrick launched arbitration proceedings with the World Bank's arbitration court, known as ICSID, in December 2024.

It had wanted ICSID to urgently address issues including the ongoing detention of four of its staff members, the appointment of a provisional administrator to operate the Loulo-Gounkoto complex after Barrick had suspended operations amid the dispute, and the expiration of the Loulo mine's license in 2026.

The request was rejected this week, the two sources said.

ICSID said on its website that it had issued an order concerning "provisional measures" on Wednesday, without giving further detail.

Barrick declined to comment on the situation. ICSID and the Malian mines ministry did not respond to requests for comment.

data.title: 'Dino' cryptos to soak up institutional funds bound for altcoins: Analyst
data.description:
Older cryptocurrencies with an exchange-traded fund (ETF) or expected to receive an ETF will soak up much of the capital deployed during the next altcoin season, according to Maen Ftouni, CEO of CoinQuant, a company that produces algorithmic trading tools. 

“Not every single coin is going to have massive returns; the liquidity is going to be concentrated into certain places, dinosaurs being one of them, of course,” Ftouni told Cointelegraph at the Global Blockchain Congress 2025 in Dubai, UAE.

Ftouni said institutional capital will be directed toward “dinosaur” coins, and attributed the 2024 rally in older cryptocurrencies like XRP and Cardano (ADA) to this phenomenon. He said:

“Since the flow of funds is coming mostly from traditional finance and ETFs at the moment, those people are probably looking at these major coins, all the coins established that have the potential of getting an ETF, and this is why we're seeing this rise in these dinosaurs.”

The prediction comes amid a debate between market analysts about the structure and market dynamics of the crypto market and how this will affect the onset of altseaon, a sustained rally in altcoin prices, during the current market cycle. 

Analysts speculate: When will altseason come, if at all?

There are over 26 million different crypto tokens listed on CoinMarketCap — more than double the amount of digital assets listed on the website at the beginning of 2025.

“Too many tokens, infinitely more to come, the supply of tokens is greater than demand,” economist and trader Alex Kruger said.

Kruger told traders to adjust their expectations and said that an “alteason” defined by a sustained period of rising asset prices likely will not happen during the current market cycle due to the changed dynamic.

Instead, traders should expect short bursts of rising altcoin prices that will only affect select tokens and may only last for several weeks at a time, Kruger added.

data.title: CBOT corn ends nearly flat as traders assess US-China deal
data.description:
Chicago Board of Trade corn futures finished nearly unchanged on Friday after Washington and Beijing did not mention specific trade commitments for the grain in a trade deal on Thursday, traders said.

  • Spillover support from gains in CBOT soybeans helped to underpin corn prices, they said.

  • U.S. harvesting was winding down amid talk that crop yields fell short of summertime expectations.

  • Farmers sold some crops after prices on Thursday reached their highest level since early July, traders said.

  • CBOT December corn (CZ25) rose 1-1/4 cent to close at $4.31-1/2 per bushel. The contract jumped about 1.9% for the week.

data.title: Tunisia sentences vocal critic of president to five years in jail
data.description:
By Tarek Amara

A Tunisian court sentenced a prominent critic of President Kais Saied to five years in prison on Friday, the latest in a series of actions targeting opposition figures who accuse Saied of using the judiciary to cement what they say is his authoritarian rule.

Ahmed Souab, a former administrative judge, was convicted by an anti-terrorism court in Tunis. He was detained in April over comments criticising the judiciary and describing the country's judges as working "with a knife to their heads".

Tunisian authorities said the remark was a threat, while Souab’s defence said it referred to the political pressure faced by the judiciary.

"Five years in prison, for what? For a figurative phrase, a spontaneous expression that everyone understood as symbolic, except the authorities. Ahmed Souab is imprisoned in our place," said his lawyer Sami Ben Ghazi.

This week, three prominent NGOs announced that the authorities had suspended their activities over alleged foreign funding — a move they described as an attempt to silence the strong voice of civil society .

Since Saied seized wide-ranging powers in 2021, dissolving parliament and ruling by decree, opponents say he has destroyed the independence of the judiciary.

He dissolved the Supreme Judicial Council and sacked dozens of judges in 2022 — moves that opposition groups and rights advocates condemned as a coup.

Most opposition leaders are in prison on various charges, including Rached Ghannouchi, head of the opposition Ennahda party, and Abir Moussi, leader of the Free Constitutional Party.

Saied denies using the judiciary against his political opponents and says he is cleansing the country of what he calls traitors and corrupt figures, adding that judges who acquit them are their accomplices. He says he will not be a dictator.
